author: Michael Larabel
description: Mesa 25.3 is out tonight as the newest quarterly feature release to this set of (predominantly) OpenGL and Vulkan drivers widely used across Linux systems. Mesa 25.3 features numerous Vulkan extensions added to the different open-source drivers, continued enhancements to the OpenGL drivers, and various other changes...
title: Mesa 25.3 Released With Many Open-Source Vulkan Driver Improvements

author: Michael Larabel
description: Ahead of the Wine 11.0 code freeze beginning in early December, Wine 10.19 is out today as the newest bi-weekly development release for running Windows games and applications on Linux...
title: Wine 10.19 Released With More Improvements

author: Michael Larabel
description: Sent out today is likely the last batch of AMDGPU kernel graphics driver feature updates ahead of the Linux 6.19 merge window getting underway around the start of December. And it's an exciting one too from adding a new SMART POWER OLED feature to switching from the Radeon to AMDGPU drivers by default for aging GCN 1.0 Southern Islands and GCN 1.1 Sea Islands GPUs...
title: AMD GCN 1.0/1.1 GPUs Will Default To AMDGPU Driver In Linux 6.19, SMART POWER OLED Added

author: Michael Larabel
description: ollama 0.12.11 released this week as the newest feature update to this easy-to-run method of deploying OpenAI GPT-OSS, DeepSeek-R1, Gemma 3, and other large language models. Exciting with ollama 0.12.11 is that it's now supporting the Vulkan API...
title: ollama 0.12.11 Brings Vulkan Acceleration

author: Michael Larabel
description: Vulkan 1.4.333 is out with a handful of fixes plus two new extensions...
title: Vulkan 1.4.333 Released With New Ray-Tracing Extension

author: Michael Larabel
description: AMD's GAIA open-source project as a reminder is their "Generrative AI Is Awesome" quick-setup solution for demonstrating generative AI use on AMD hardware platforms with Ryzen CPUs, Radeon GPUs, and/or Ryzen AI NPUs. GAIA is predominantly Microsoft Windows focused but recently they did introduce limited support for Linux that is currently bound to Vulkan-accelerated GPU support. Out today is AMD GAIA 0.13 as another step forward for this AI demonstrator...
title: AMD GAIA 0.13 Released With New AI Coding & Docker Agents

author: Michael Larabel
description: While the "Nova" driver continues to be developed as a modern Rust-written, open-source and in-kernel NVIDIA graphics driver for Linux, for the time being Nouveau is what's working for end-users for those wanting a mainline open-source NVIDIA graphics driver for gaming and other workloads. With Linux 6.19 the Nouveau driver is picking up support for handling larger pages as well as compression support...
title: Nouveau Driver To Support Larger Pages & Compression Support With Linux 6.19

author: Michael Larabel
description: Intel today sent out their last batch of planned feature patches for their Xe kernel graphics driver of material intended for Linux 6.19...
title: Intel Submits Last Batch Of Xe Driver Feature Updates For Linux 6.19

author: Michael Larabel
description: Introduced last year in the Linux 6.10 kernel was the mseal system call for memory sealing to protect the memory mapping against modifications to seal non-writable memory segments or better protecting sensitive data structures. The GNU C Library has finally introduced its mseal function making use of this modern Linux kernel functionality...
title: GNU C Library Adds Linux "mseal" Function For Memory Sealing

author: Michael Larabel
description: Following the mainline Linux kernel support for the VisionFive 2 RISC-V single board computer from StarFive, Linux kernel patches are on the way for their new VisionFive 2 Lite low-cost offering. With the StarFive VisionFive 2 Lite this RISC-V board can be procured for as little as $19.9 USD as one of the cheapest yet fairly capable RISC-V SBCs...
title: Mainline Linux Patches For The VisionFive 2 Lite: RISC-V For As Little As $19.9 USD

author: Michael Larabel
description: Intel driver engineer Suraj Kandpal presented at the recent X.Org Developer's Conference (XDC2025) on the challenges around supporting content protection on Linux such as for High-bandwidth Digital Content Protection (HDCP) and Protected Audio Video Path (PAVP)...
title: The Headaches Supporting Content Protection With Linux GPU Drivers

author: Michael Larabel
description: Fedora 44 is looking at replacing the Linux kernel's console "FBCON" with the user-space-based KMSCON implementation. Eventually the hope remains to deprecate the FBCON/FBDEV code within the Linux kernel...
title: Fedora 44 Looking At Replacing FBCON With KMSCON As Default VT Console

author: Michael Larabel
description: Compiler engineer Marek Polacek of Red Hat recently proposed making the C++20 language specification (or rather the GNU++20 dialect) the default C++ version when not otherwise specified...
title: GCC Compiler Developers Begin Considering C++20 Default
